System modules¶

System module is a building block of your application. The main difference between normal modules and system modules is a type of module’s parent. The parent of system module is an application related management command, like cmdline for command line application or webapp for web application. These management commands are responsible for chosing a proper configuration manager, creation of devices, modules and commands of your application and other low level tasks. Having a reference to the application management command, a system module has access to configuration, other system modules, managers of devices, commands and modules of your application. All system modules: Logger, Application, Virtual Machine and Authentication, presented currently in PyFRID are described in the following subsections.

Base System Module¶

System Module class and functions¶

Application Module¶

Application module systematize devices, commands and modules of your application, except system modules of course. It also plays a role of a sandbox for them, giving a limited access to the functionality of other system modules like authentication, logger and virtual machine. It also contains useful generators to iterate over objects and methods which can be used in other modules and commands during the runtime of application.

Application Module class and functions¶

class pyfrid.modules.system.app.BaseApplicationModule(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is base class for application module. The application module is a system module which manages devices, commands and modules of your application, executes and validates the code by using virtual_machine system module, control permissions to objects using authentication module. It also has useful tools for developers to iterate over objects of different types.

busy[source]¶

Calls property of the same name of virtual_machine module.

commands(permission='')[source]¶

Returns a list of names of commands presented in application.

devices(permission='')[source]¶

Returns a list of names of devices presented in application.

execute_code(code)[source]¶

Executes a code in another thread. Before execution every system module including application module is released.

get_command(name, permission='', byname=False, exc=False)[source]¶

Returns command presented in application by its name or alias depending on permissions (if given). if exc is True the exception will be raised if command was not found.

get_device(name, permission='', byname=False, exc=False)[source]¶

Returns device presented in application by its name or alias depending on permissions (if given). if exc is True the exception will be raised if device was not found.

get_module(name, permission='', byname=False, exc=False)[source]¶

Returns module presented in application by its name or alias depending on permissions (if given). if exc is True the exception will be raised if module was not found.

initialize()[source]¶

Initialization handler. It iterates over all devices, modules and commands and calls initialize handler of each object.

iterate_commands(permission='', byname=False)[source]¶

Iterator over commands in application. It yields a tuple (name, reference) for every command depending on permissions (if given). If argument byname is False this iterator will return command alias.

iterate_devices(permission='', byname=False)[source]¶

Iterator over devices in application. It yields a tuple (name, reference) for every device depending on permissions (if given). If argument byname is False this iterator will return device alias.

iterate_modules(permission='', byname=False)[source]¶

Iterator over modules presented in application. It yields a tuple (name, reference) for every module depending on permissions (if given). If argument byname is False this iterator will return module alias.

iterate_objects(permission='', byname=False)[source]¶

Iterator over devices, commands and modules presented in application. It yields a tuple (name, reference) for every object depending on permissions (if given). If argument byname is False this iterator will return object alias.

iterate_sysmods(permission='', byname=False)[source]¶

Iterator over system modules presented in application. It yields a tuple (name, reference) for every module depending on permissions (if given). If argument byname is False this iterator will return module alias.

login(login, password)[source]¶

Calls function of the same name of authentication module.

logout(login, password)[source]¶

Calls function of the same name of authentication module.

modules(permission='')[source]¶

Returns a list of names of modules presented in application.

objects(permission='')[source]¶

Returns a list of names of devices, commands and modules presented in application.

projname[source]¶

Returns application name

projpath[source]¶

Returns path to application

release()[source]¶

Release handler. It iterates over all devices, modules and commands and calls release handler of each object. This handler is executed before running a command or a code.

shutdown()[source]¶

Shutdown handler. It iterates over all devices, modules and commands and calls shutdown handler of each object.

status()[source]¶

Status handler for application module. By default it shows number of devices, commands and modules in application

stop()[source]¶

Shutdown handler. It iterates over all devices, modules and commands and calls stop handler of each object. Stopping is performed in another thread in order to avoid any blocking of the main thread of application.

sysmods(permission='')[source]¶

Returns a list of names of system modules presented in application.

validate_access(obj, permission)[source]¶

Validates access to an object by checking object’s permission.

validate_code(code)[source]¶

Validates a code in another thread.

Virtual Machine Module¶

Base Virtual Machine Module class and functions¶

class pyfrid.modules.system.vm.core.vm.BaseVMModule(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is base class of a virtual machine module. It has basic functionality and defines few abstract methods, which must be implemented in subclasses.

busy[source]¶

Returns True if there is a running command.

current_line[source]¶

Returns a current line of a macro.

current_macro[source]¶

Returns a filename of a currently running macro.

elapsed[source]¶

Returns an estimated elapsed time.

err_stop¶

boolean setting which indicates whether to stop execution of a command or a macro when error was emitted

exc_stop¶

boolean setting which indicates whether to stop execution of a command or a macro when exception was emitted

execute_ast(ast)[source]¶

Abstract method which executes a code, normally after parsing and validation.

execute_code(code)[source]¶

Main method, which performs execution of a code. Before execution the signal before_execute_signal is emitted. If parsing and validation of a code were successful, this function starts execution of a AST.

finishes[source]¶

Returns an estimated time when a currently running command or macro will be finished.

parse_code(code)[source]¶

Abstract method which parses a code.

runtime[source]¶

Returns an estimated running time of a command or a macro.

started[source]¶

Returns time stamp when a macro or a command was started.

status()[source]¶

Status handler of this module. It returns a current running filename, current line, time when a command was started, estimated runtime, elapsed time and time when current command will finish.

validate_ast(ast)[source]¶

Abstract method which validates a code and returns its estimated runtime, normally after parsing it.

validate_code(code)[source]¶

Method for a code validation.

Lepl Virtual Machine Module class and functions¶

class pyfrid.modules.system.vm.leplvm.BaseLeplVMModule(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is virtual machine system module, based on LEPL parser.

class pyfrid.modules.system.vm.leplvm.BaseNode[source]¶

Base Node class for all nodes.

process()[source]¶

Analyzes the parameters and returns the value

class pyfrid.modules.system.vm.leplvm.CmdStmtNode[source]¶

Class of macro command node

class pyfrid.modules.system.vm.leplvm.ValueNode[source]¶

Base node for the constants While processing returns the value transformed to the given type. Type can be any function of the form def type_(string):

do_something and return
type_¶

alias of str

Authentication Module¶

Base Authentication Module class and functions¶

class pyfrid.modules.system.auth.core.auth.BaseAuthModule(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is base class of authentication module. This module has functions for login and logout of a user, validating access of a user to objects presented in application. It also contains abstract methods for user creation and deleting. By default the authentication module has several useful signals:

  • before_login_signal
  • after_login_signal
  • before_logout_signal
  • after_logout_signal
add_user(login, password, groups, name, email, organization)[source]¶

Abstract method which adds user. The information about users is kept in a different way depending on the type of authentication module.

current_login[source]¶

Returns login of a currently logged in user or empty string

current_user[source]¶

Returns a user object from top of the stack (i.e. current user) or None if there is no user logged in.

del_user(login)[source]¶

Abstract method which deletes user.

groups = {'GUEST': 30, 'ROOT': 0, 'ADVUSER': 10, 'USER': 20}¶

user groups and their weights. Groups with smaller are more powerful.

login(login, password)[source]¶

This function first validates login and password and creates User object, which corresponds to them. If validation was successful and there is no current user in application, this user become the current one. If there is another user currently signed in and his group weight is smaller (he has more rights), login fails. If the current user has less rights then one which is trying to login, then new user is added to the top of the stack and become the current user. This function return true or False depending on the result of the login process.

logout(login, password)[source]¶

Performs a logout of a current user from application after validation of login and password.

noauth[source]¶

Returns True if authentication module doesn’t perform any login or logout.

status()[source]¶

Status handler with some information about a current user.

user_exists(login)[source]¶

Returns True if user with login login exists or False.

validate_access(getter, permission='', exc=False)[source]¶

This function checks whether a current user has access to an object. The argument getter can be an object which has method get_permission_groups or a function which accepts permission as an argument and returns a list of user groups corresponding to permission.

validate_user(login, password)[source]¶

Abstract method which checks login and password and returns a User object which corresponds to them.

NoAuthentication Module class and functions¶

class pyfrid.modules.system.auth.noauth.BaseNoAuthModule(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is authentication module which doesn’t perform any login and logout and all access validations will return True. Use it if you don’t need any authentication control in your application.

add_user(login, password, groups, name, email, organization)[source]¶

Raises NotImplementedError.

del_user(login)[source]¶

Raises NotImplementedError.

noauth[source]¶

Returns True

user_exists(login)[source]¶

Raises NotImplementedError.

validate_access(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Always returns True

validate_user(login, password)[source]¶

Returns empty user.

Yaml Authentication Module class and functions¶

class pyfrid.modules.system.auth.yamlauth.BaseYamlAuthModule(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is a simple authentication module which uses YAML file to keep information about users and their login and passwords. Passwords a encoded with sha224 algorithm.

dbpath¶

path to YAML file with users information

Logger Module¶

Base Logger Module class and functions¶

class pyfrid.modules.system.logger.BaseLoggerModule(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

This is base logger module, system module which manages logging messages of your application. It is based on the standard python logging module, where log messages are emitted by handlers. PyFRID logger supports by default logging to stdout, file and email.

debugmode¶

boolean fixed setting for switching on/off debugging mode

email_log¶

boolean fixed setting for switching on/off logging to email of a current user

file_log¶

boolean fixed setting for switching on/off logging to a log file

logdir¶

string fixed setting for the path to a directory with log file

smtp_from¶

string setting for the from email.

smtp_host¶

string setting for the smtp host. It is used for the logging to email.

smtp_pass¶

string setting for the smtp password.

smtp_port¶

integer setting for the smtp port.

smtp_secure¶

string setting for the smtp secure type.

smtp_user¶

string setting for the smtp user.

stdout_log¶

boolean fixed setting for switching on/off logging to standard output
